name: The Lord of the Ring
title: This trilogy by J.R.R. Tolkien was incredibly popular when it was first published over 60 years ago.

name: The Adventures of Sherlock Holmes
title: A collection of twelve short stories featuring the famous detective, Sherlock Holmes.

name: Pride and Prejudice
title: A classic novel by Jane Austen that explores the manners and matrimonial machinations of the British gentry.

name: Moby Dick
title: Herman Melville’s classic about Ahab's obsessive quest for revenge on Moby Dick, the great white whale.
George Orwell's dystopian novel about a totalitarian regime that uses surveillance, censorship, and control.

name: The Great Gatsby
title: F. Scott Fitzgerald's novel of the Jazz Age, exploring themes of wealth, love, and the American dream.

name: Frankenstein
title: Mary Shelley's Gothic novel that explores the consequences of creating life and playing god.

name: Dracula
title: Bram Stoker's vampire novel that introduced Count Dracula and established many conventions of vampire fantasy.

name: War and Peace
title: Leo Tolstoy's historical novel set during the Napoleonic wars in Russia, exploring themes of fate and free will.

name: The Odyssey
title: Homer's epic poem recounting Odysseus's adventures as he struggles to return home from the Trojan War.

name: Jane Eyre
title: Charlotte Brontë's novel about an orphaned girl’s journey to adulthood and her love for Mr. Rochester.

name: To Kill a Mockingbird
title: Harper Lee's classic novel about racial injustice and childhood innocence in the Deep South.

name: The Catcher in the Rye
title: J.D. Salinger's iconic novel about teenage alienation and rebellion, told through the eyes of Holden Caulfield.

name: Brave New World
title: Aldous Huxley’s dystopian novel exploring a world of advanced technology, social control, and the loss of individuality.

name: The Hobbit
title: J.R.R. Tolkien's prelude to 'The Lord of the Rings,' following Bilbo Baggins' journey to reclaim treasure guarded by a dragon.

name: The Brothers Karamazov
title: Fyodor Dostoevsky's philosophical novel examining faith, free will, and the nature of human suffering.

name: Les Misérables
title: Victor Hugo's epic story of love, justice, and redemption in post-revolutionary France.

name: Anna Karenina
title: Leo Tolstoy’s tragic novel of passion and infidelity set against the backdrop of Russian aristocratic society.

name: Don Quixote
title: Miguel de Cervantes' comic novel about the adventures of a man who believes himself to be a knight.

name: Fahrenheit 451
title: Ray Bradbury’s dystopian novel about a future society where books are banned and 'firemen' burn them.

name: The Picture of Dorian Gray
title: Oscar Wilde's novel about a young man whose portrait ages while he remains young and beautiful, leading to moral corruption.

name: The Catch-22
title: Joseph Heller's satirical novel about the absurdities of war and the bureaucratic rule that no one can escape.

name: The Road
title: Cormac McCarthy's post-apocalyptic novel about a father and son journeying through a desolate America.

name: The Alchemist
title: Paulo Coelho's philosophical tale of a shepherd's journey to discover his personal legend and destiny.

name: The Road Less Traveled
title: M. Scott Peck's self-help book offering insights on personal growth and spiritual development.

name: The Secret Garden
title: Frances Hodgson Burnett's classic children's novel about a neglected girl who discovers a hidden, magical garden.

name: A Tale of Two Cities
title: Charles Dickens' historical novel set before and during the French Revolution, exploring themes of resurrection and sacrifice.

name: The Bell Jar
title: Sylvia Plath's semi-autobiographical novel about a young woman's descent into mental illness and her struggle for identity.

name: The Kite Runner
title: Khaled Hosseini's powerful story of friendship and betrayal set against the backdrop of a changing Afghanistan.

name: The Fault in Our Stars
title: John Green's poignant novel about two teenagers who fall in love while battling cancer.
